questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with hypopigmented nodular lesions with anethesia over arm with ulnar nerve involvement underwent a biopsy and intradermal antigen test. Based on the image, which statement regarding the condition is most accurate?

choices.text: Tuberculoid leprosy with a positive antigen test
Lepromatous leprosy with a positive antigen test
Erythema nodosum leprosum with a negative antigen test
Lepromatous leprosy with a negative antigen test

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lepromatous leprosy with a negative antigen test

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of this 38-year-old patient includes:

  • Multiple hypopigmented nodular skin lesions

  • Loss of sensation (anaesthesia)

  • Involvement of peripheral nerves (ulnar nerve)

  • Biopsy and intradermal antigen test (likely the Lepromin test)

These features are most consistent with lepromatous leprosy, a multibacillary form of Hansen’s disease.

Feature Description
Skin lesions Numerous, symmetric, poorly defined, nodular or macular
Sensory loss Late, diffuse
Nerve involvement Multiple nerves, symmetrically
Immune response Weak or absent cell-mediated immunity (CMI)
Lepromin (Mitsuda) test Negative (due to poor CMI)
Bacillary load High
Histopathology Numerous acid-fast bacilli, foamy macrophages

 

Tuberculoid leprosy with a positive antigen test (Option A): Tuberculoid form presents with few well-demarcated lesions, strong CMI, positive Lepromin test — not nodular lesions or widespread nerve involvement.

 

Lepromatous leprosy with a positive antigen test (Option B): Lepromatous type is associated with negative Lepromin test.

 

Erythema nodosum leprosum (Option C): ENL is a type II lepra reaction, typically in patients already diagnosed with lepromatous leprosy, presenting with tender nodules, fever, systemic symptoms — not primary presentation.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a pregnant woman who is 12 weeks pregnant and undergoing multidrug therapy for leprosy but is now experiencing type 2 lepra reaction?

choices.text: Stop MDT and start oral steroids

Thalidomide

Continue MDT and add oral steroids
Continue MDT and add oral steroids

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Continue MDT and add oral steroids

 

Explanation:

Type 2 lepra reaction (erythema nodosum leprosum, ENL) is an immune complex-mediated reaction seen in multibacillary leprosy. Pregnancy does not alter the management of leprosy itself, and stopping multidrug therapy (MDT) is not recommended. The preferred treatment for type 2 reactions includes oral corticosteroids, which are safe in pregnancy. Thalidomide is strictly contraindicated due to teratogenicity.

Leprosy and Its Management in Pregnancy

Aspect

Details

Cause of Leprosy

Mycobacterium leprae

Types of Reactions

Type 1 (Reversal), Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

Type 2 Lepra Reaction

Immune complex-mediated (Type III hypersensitivity)

Common Symptoms

Painful nodules, fever, malaise, neuritis

Management of Type 2 Reaction

Corticosteroids (safe in pregnancy)

Role of MDT in Pregnancy

Must be continued to prevent relapse

Drugs to Avoid

Thalidomide (teratogenic)

 

Management of Type 2 Lepra Reaction in Pregnancy

Aspect

Details

Continue MDT

Essential to prevent disease relapse

Preferred drug

Oral steroids (prednisolone)

Avoid in pregnancy

Thalidomide (teratogenic, causes phocomelia)

Supportive therapy

Analgesics, wound care if ulcerated lesions present

Alternative options

Clofazimine has mild immunomodulatory effects

 

Stop MDT and start oral steroids (Option A) is incorrect because stopping MDT can lead to disease relapse and worsening nerve damage. MDT must be continued while managing the reaction with steroids.

 

Antibiotics (Option B) is incorrect because type 2 lepra reaction is an inflammatory immune response, not an infectious complication. Antibiotics have no role in managing ENL itself.

 

Thalidomide (Option C) is incorrect because thalidomide is highly teratogenic (causing phocomelia and limb defects) and is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy. Although thalidomide is an effective treatment for ENL, it should never be used in pregnant women.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the clinic with hypopigmented patches on the skin. On examination, there are a few well-demarcated, slightly raised lesions with a loss of sensation. Skin smears reveal no acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Paucibacillary leprosy

 

Explanation:

  • Hypopigmented patches with sensory loss strongly suggest leprosy rather than other dermatological conditions.
  • Well-demarcated, slightly raised lesions are characteristic of paucibacillary leprosy, which presents with five or fewer skin lesions with nerve involvement.
  • Skin smears revealing no acid-fast bacilli indicate a low bacterial load, confirming paucibacillary leprosy rather than multibacillary leprosy.

Leprosy:

Leprosy (Hansen’s disease) is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, primarily affecting the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucosa of the upper respiratory tract. It presents in a spectrum based on bacterial load and immune response.

Classification of Leprosy (Ridley-Jopling & WHO Classification)

Clinical Features of Leprosy

System Involved

Clinical Features

Skin

Hypopigmented or erythematous macules, plaques, nodules, loss of sweating (anhidrosis)

Nerves

Thickened peripheral nerves, sensory loss (glove and stocking pattern)

Eyes

Lagophthalmos, keratitis, blindness

Musculoskeletal

Claw hand, foot drop, joint deformities

Systemic

Testicular atrophy, gynecomastia (LL type)

 

Diagnosis of Leprosy

Diagnostic Method

Findings

Clinical Diagnosis

Hypopigmented/anesthetic skin lesions, nerve thickening

Skin Smear (Ziehl-Neelsen Stain)

AFB seen in multibacillary leprosy but not in paucibacillary leprosy

Lepromin Test

Positive in tuberculoid leprosy, negative in lepromatous leprosy

Skin Biopsy

Granulomas in tuberculoid leprosy, foam cells in lepromatous leprosy

Nerve Biopsy

Shows caseation necrosis in tuberculoid type

 

Treatment of Leprosy (WHO Multidrug Therapy – MDT)

Type

First-Line Treatment (Duration)

Paucibacillary (PB)

Rifampicin + Dapsone (6 months)

Multibacillary (MB)

Rifampicin + Dapsone + Clofazimine (12 months)
  • Pregnancy & lactation: MDT is safe.
  • Children: Treated with adjusted doses based on weight.

Leprosy Reactions & Management

Reaction Type

Features

Treatment

Type 1 (Reversal)

Inflammatory response in existing lesions, nerve damage

Steroids (Prednisolone)

Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL)

Painful nodules, fever, neuritis, systemic involvement

Steroids, Clofazimine, avoid Thalidomide in pregnancy

Lucio Phenomenon

Ulcerative necrotizing lesions

Rifampicin, Clofazimine

 

Prevention & Public Health Measures

  • BCG vaccine offers partial protection.
  • Early diagnosis & MDT prevents transmission.
  • Household contacts should be screened regularly.
  • Reconstructive surgery for deformities in chronic cases.

 

Multibacillary leprosy (Option A) is incorrect because MB leprosy presents with multiple lesions, often widespread, with no sensory impairment in early stages and a positive skin smear for Mycobacterium leprae (acid-fast bacilli). This patient’s negative smear and limited lesion count favour paucibacillary leprosy.

 

Psoriasis (Option B) is incorrect because psoriatic plaques are erythematous with silvery scales, not hypopigmented. Sensory loss is not a feature of psoriasis, and skin smears do not play a role in its diagnosis.

 

Tinea versicolor (Option C) is incorrect because pityriasis (tinea) versicolor, caused by Malassezia spp., presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented macules, but there is no sensory loss. The lesions are typically scaly, and a KOH mount would reveal spaghetti and meatballs appearance (yeast and hyphae).

questions.text: The image given below is characteristically seen in which of the following types of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Borderline leprosy

Explanation:

Borderline leprosy is part of the spectrum of Hansen’s disease (leprosy) and is characterised by:

  • Variable number of hypopigmented or hyperpigmented lesions that are asymmetrically distributed.
  • Patchy partial loss of sensation within the lesions, a key diagnostic clue.
  • Borderline forms are unstable, and patients may shift toward either the lepromatous or tuberculoid pole.
  • Scalp involvement is uncommon in most forms of leprosy but can be seen in borderline cases.

Ridley-Jopling Classification of Leprosy:

  1. Tuberculoid leprosy (TT) – Few well-demarcated hypopigmented patches with complete loss of sensation. Strong cell-mediated immunity (CMI).
  2. Borderline tuberculoid (BT) – Multiple asymmetrical lesions, less well-defined than TT, with some sensory loss.
  3. Borderline leprosy (BB) – Intermediate form, variable lesions with partial sensory loss, and patchy nerve involvement.
  4. Borderline lepromatous (BL) – Numerous lesions resembling LL but with some sensory impairment.
  5. Lepromatous leprosy (LL) – Diffuse, symmetrical lesions with loss of eyebrows, leonine facies, and late nerve damage. Poor CMI response.

 

Borderline lepromatous leprosy (Option A) is incorrect because it shows more numerous lesions that resemble lepromatous leprosy but still have some sensory impairment. However, they are not as widespread as in full lepromatous leprosy.

Lepromatous leprosy (Option B) is incorrect because it presents with numerous, symmetrical macules, papules, or nodules with a loss of sensation late in the disease due to nerve involvement. Lesions lack the clear borders seen in borderline cases.

Histoid leprosy (Option D) is incorrect because it is a variant of lepromatous leprosy with shiny, smooth, well-demarcated nodules or plaques, commonly on the back, extremities, and face. It is seen in patients with dapsone resistance or relapsed leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following will be the outcome of Leprosy , if left untreated.

choices.text: Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure
Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults
Indeterminate leprosy have more remission than tuberculoid

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Indeterminate leprosy have more remission than tuberculoid

Explanation:

  • Indeterminate leprosy is the earliest form of leprosy, presenting with a single or few ill-defined hypopigmented macules and minimal sensory loss.
  • In many cases, spontaneous remission occurs, particularly in individuals with a strong cell-mediated immune (CMI) response.
  • Tuberculoid leprosy, while having a strong immune response, tends to be chronic and persistent, with less likelihood of spontaneous remission.

Indeterminate Leprosy:

  • Early, undifferentiated form of leprosy.
  • Few hypopigmented macules with slight sensory impairment.
  • Histopathology: Mild inflammation, sparse acid-fast bacilli (AFB).
  • Fate:
    • Can resolve spontaneously (~25–75% of cases).
    • May progress to tuberculoid or lepromatous forms, depending on immune response.

Tuberculoid Leprosy:

  • Well-demarcated plaques with sensory loss, few lesions.
  • Strong CMI response, granuloma formation.
  • Less likely to remit spontaneously, tends to persist unless treated.

Outcomes if Untreated:

  • Indeterminate leprosy has a higher chance of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.
  • If it does not resolve, it may progress toward the tuberculoid or lepromatous spectrum based on immune status.

 

No spontaneous remission is seen (Option A) is incorrect because spontaneous remission does occur, particularly in indeterminate and early tuberculoid leprosy, especially in individuals with good immunity.

Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure (Option B) is incorrect because while some individuals clear the infection, the proportion is variable and not as high as 50% in all populations.

Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults (Option C) is incorrect because although children may have a higher rate of spontaneous resolution, the likelihood of remission is more dependent on the type of leprosy (indeterminate vs tuberculoid) rather than age alone.

questions.text: What would be your next best course of action when a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) exhibits deterioration of preexisting lesions and nerve involvement?

choices.text: Stop MDT thalidomide Continue MDT, start thalidomide

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

Explanation:

  • Deterioration of preexisting lesions + nerve involvement in a patient on MDT suggests Type 1 Lepra Reaction (Reversal Reaction).
  • Type 1 Reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction in borderline leprosy due to increased cell-mediated immunity.
  • Management:
    • Continue MDT: The reaction is due to immune response, not drug failure.
    • Start systemic corticosteroids (prednisolone) to reduce inflammation and prevent permanent nerve damage.

Lepra Reactions

Type

Mechanism

Clinical Features

Management

Type 1 (Reversal Reaction)

Increased cell-mediated immunity (CMI)

Worsening of existing lesions, erythema, edema, nerve pain

Continue MDT, start systemic steroids (prednisolone)

Type 2 (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum - ENL)

Immune complex deposition (TNF-α mediated)

Painful nodules, fever, neuritis, systemic symptoms

Continue MDT, start thalidomide or steroids

Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids (Option A): Incorrect because MDT should not be stopped; the reaction is due to immune response, not drug toxicity.

Stop MDT, start thalidomide (Option C): Incorrect because thalidomide is used for Type 2 reaction (ENL), not Type 1 reaction.

Continue MDT, start thalidomide (Option D): Incorrect because thalidomide is ineffective for Type 1 reactions; steroids are preferred.

questions.text: Please determine the medication utilized for the management of the presented medical condition:
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Anti-tubercular therapy

Explanation:

  • The image shows annular plaque with central scarring which is suggestive of Lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. It presents as a chronic, slowly progressive skin lesion with an annular (ring-shaped) plaque and central scarring.
  • Anti-tubercular therapy: Anti-tubercular therapy is the treatment of choice for lupus vulgaris. It consists of a combination of drugs, including isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. These medications target Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative organism, and aim to eradicate the infection.

Cutaneous TB:

Exogenous:

Endogenous:
  • Source of MTB is from outside the body
  • First exposure to TB - new to TB infection is Naive infection
    • Called TB chance
    • No immunity
  • Once had TB but now recurred due to Exogenous causes:
    • Tuberculosis Verrucous cutis (TBVC)
    • Immunity present
  • Source is within the body
  • Transmitted to skin by:
    • Contiguous (ex: lymphatic TB breaking into skin) - Scrofuloderma
    • Hematogenous - Lupus vulgaris, TB gumma and miliary TB
    • Auto miliary TB
    • Auto inoculation - or Orificial TB

1. TB Chancre / Primary Inoculation TB

2. TBVC or Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis

1. Lupus Vulgaris

Apple jelly nodules on diascopy

2. Scrofuloderma

3. Orificial Tuberculosis

Management

  • All forms of cutaneous TB have the same treatment.
  • Total 6 months treatment:
    • 2 months: Intensive phase = HERZ for 2 months.
    • 4 months: Maintenance phase = HRE for 4 months.
  • HERZ = Isoniazid, ethambutol, rifampicin and pyrazinamide.
  • Doses
    • Isoniazid (H): 5mg/kg/day
    • Rifampicin = 10 mg/kg/day
    • Ethambutol (E): 15 mg/kg/day
    • Streptomycin (S): 15 mg/kg/day
    • Pyrazinamide (P): 25 mg/kg/day


Incorrect Options:

Anti-fungal therapy (Option A) is not the appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris. While superficial fungal infections can also present as annular lesions, the clinical presentation and diagnostic criteria mentioned in the question suggest a mycobacterial infection rather than a fungal infection.

Topical steroids therapy (Option C): Topical steroid therapy is not the primary treatment for lupus vulgaris. While topical steroids may be used in some cases to alleviate inflammation and itching, they do not address the underlying mycobacterial infection and are not the mainstay of treatment.

Anti-leprosy treatment (Option D): Anti-leprosy treatment is not the correct choice for lupus vulgaris. Leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae, is a separate disease entity and requires specific anti-leprosy drugs for treatment. It is not indicated for the management of lupus vulgaris.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of neuritic leprosy, which nerve is typically subjected to a biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • Neuritic leprosy, also known as pure neuritic leprosy, is a form of leprosy that primarily affects the peripheral nerves without significant skin involvement. It is characterized by nerve damage and inflammation, leading to sensory and motor impairments.
  • To diagnose neuritic leprosy, a nerve biopsy is often performed to examine the affected nerve tissue for the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, the bacteria that causes leprosy. The superficial branch of the radial nerve is commonly chosen for the biopsy due to its accessibility and involvement in the affected nerve region.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Median nerve: The median nerve is not typically biopsied for the diagnosis of neuritic leprosy. While it can be affected in leprosy, it is not the primary nerve chosen for biopsy in cases of neuritic leprosy.

Option C. Ulnar nerve: Similar to the median nerve, the ulnar nerve can be affected in leprosy, but it is not the nerve of choice for biopsy in cases of neuritic leprosy.

Option D. Lateral popliteal nerve: The lateral popliteal nerve, also known as the common peroneal nerve, is not specifically associated with neuritic leprosy. While leprosy can affect peripheral nerves throughout the body, the superficial branch of the radial nerve is the nerve commonly biopsied for the diagnosis of neuritic leprosy, not the lateral popliteal nerve.

questions.text:
A patient presents with a progressive and asymptomatic lesion over the neck region and no systemic symptoms. Which of the following investigations would be helpful?




	KOH preparation
	Skin biopsy
	Chest X-ray (TB workup)
	HIV testing
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2,3

Explanation:

In a patient with a progressive, asymptomatic lesion over the neck, clinically suggestive of Lupus Vulgaris (a form of cutaneous tuberculosis), the most helpful investigation would be skin biopsy and TB workup.

  • It is a chronic, progressive, paucibacillary (not multibacillary) form of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous TB seen in adults (M/C in females).
  • Causative organisms: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium bovis.
  • Pathogenesis :
    • Route of spread: Endogenous spread or from exogenous inoculation.
    • It occurs in a previously sensitized individual with an increased cell-mediated immunity to tuberculin.
  • Clinical features:
    • Presents as a single or a group of erythematous violaceous annular plaques with central scarring and atrophy with active margins.
    • The periphery shows erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules.

  • Most commonly seen in the buttocks, upper extremities, and face.
  • Papules may recur within scarred areas, enlarging and coalescing into large, firm, elevated plaques.
  • Treatment: Antitibercular therapy.
  • Complication: Secondary scarring and squamous cell carcinoma may develop rarely.

KOH preparation (Option 1) is used to detect superficial fungal infections like tinea or candidiasis by identifying fungal elements in skin scrapings. Since lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, KOH is not helpful for its diagnosis.

HIV testing (Option 4) is useful in immunocompromised patients or atypical infections, but this patient has a localized, slow-growing lesion without systemic signs. It doesn't directly help diagnose lupus vulgaris and isn't a first-line test.

questions.text: A patient with borderline tuberculoid leprosy presents with the following findings. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction and nerve is enlarged?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Type 4 & greater auricular nerve

Explanation:

The image shows a patient with a visibly thickened and enlarged nerve in the neck region, which is the greater auricular nerve. The question also mentions that the patient has borderline tuberculoid leprosy and is experiencing a reaction.

  • Leprosy Reactions: Leprosy reactions are episodes of acute inflammation that occur during the course of the disease. Type 1 (reversal) reactions are a form of delayed-type hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction. They are caused by a sudden increase in the cell-mediated immune response to the Mycobacterium leprae bacteria.
  • Clinical Presentation: These reactions often involve inflammation of existing skin lesions and, most importantly, acute neuritis, which is the painful inflammation and enlargement of peripheral nerves. The greater auricular nerve is a common site for this nerve enlargement.

Therefore, the correct pairing is a Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction and the greater auricular nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Type 1 & greater auricular nerve (Option A) is an immediate, IgE-mediated reaction (e.g., an allergic reaction), which is not what causes leprosy reactions.

Type 2 & greater auricular nerve (Option B) is a cytotoxic, antibody-mediated reaction. A Type 2 leprosy reaction is known as erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), which presents with painful red nodules and is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction.

Type 3 & anterior auricular nerve (Option C) is an immune complex-mediated reaction. A Type 2 leprosy reaction (ENL) is an example of this. The anterior auricular nerve is not the most commonly affected nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents with an indurated plaque on the cheek with central atrophy. Chest X-ray reveals apical calcification. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PCR

Explanation:

  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis, often arising from hematogenous or lymphatic spread from a latent pulmonary focus.
  • Clinical clue: indurated plaque with central atrophy on the face + old TB lesion in the lung (apical calcification).
  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA is the most sensitive and specific test to confirm cutaneous TB.
  • PCR detects bacterial DNA even when bacillary load is low (as in lupus vulgaris, which is paucibacillary).
  • While Mantoux may support diagnosis, it is not confirmatory

Lupus vulgaris

  • Chronic, progressive, paucibacillary (not multibacillary) form of cutaneous tuberculosis.
  • Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous TB seen in adults (M/C in females).
  • Causative organisms: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium bovis.

 

Pathogenesis :

  • Route of spread: Endogenous spread or from exogenous inoculation.
  • It occurs in a previously sensitized individual with an increased cell-mediated immunity to tuberculin.

 

Clinical features:

  • Presents as a single or a group of erythematous violaceous annular plaques with central scarring and atrophy with active margins.
  • The periphery shows erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules.
  • Most commonly seen in the buttocks, upper extremities, and face.
  • Papules may recur within scarred areas, enlarging and coalescing into large, firm, elevated plaques.
  • Diagnosis is often confirmed by histopathological examination of skin biopsy specimens, which typically show caseating granulomas with acid-fast bacilli.

The above image depicts the Apple Jelly Nodule

Complication:

  • Secondary scarring and squamous cell carcinoma may develop rarely.

Treatment :

  • Anti-tubercular drugs.

Mantoux test (Option A): Indicates prior sensitization to TB but cannot confirm active disease; may be positive in BCG-vaccinated individuals and other mycobacterial infections.

Slit skin smear (Option B): Useful for detecting acid-fast bacilli in leprosy, not for cutaneous TB where bacillary load is very low.

Probe test (Option D): Used in oral submucous fibrosis to assess fibrous bands in the oral mucosa; not related to lupus vulgaris diagnosis.
